Billy Ko, President - Investment Club at Singapore Institute Of TechnologyLevel 6. MasterAnswered on 02 May 2019Many of times, returns are pegged to market i.e. STI Index / S&P 500 - that is a good gauge because if you can obtain a higher return that the market, you would be considered "beating / winning the market" Alternatively, if you'd like a bigger challenge, you can peg your returns to the 'big boys' i.e. Warren Buffett or even fund managers i.e. George Soros etc.0 comments1

Li Yu, Financial Services Consultant at Manulife Financial AdvisorsLevel 3. WonderkidAnswered on 01 May 2019I agree with Hariz. There's no definite answer. It mostly depends on your own satisfactory level.Adding on to that, risk ususally increases with potential investment return. We can't look at return alone and disregard the underlying risk. What you want in the end is an investment that gives you as close to your satisfactory return as possible at a risk level that you can tolerate.0 comments1

TWTay WenHaoLevel 4. ProdigyAnswered on 02 May 2019As what others have mentioned it depends on your risk appetite as well. As the saying goes, high risk high returns.As for myself personally, i aimed at just about 5% returns per year (usually from dividends payout).Regarding insurance products, you need to keep in mind that theres a 'lock-in' period (about 10 to 20 years) and if you prematurely cancel or terminate the product you may not even get back your cost. Furthermore, the 4% is usually the 'EXPECTED' returns and not 100% guaranteed. Of course, that being said, if you are getting this for insurance purposes instead of investment then its a different story.0 comments0
